item.title: How your essay is read
item.description: Here’s the order in which an examiner reads and assesses your essay. Check whether you write in paragraphs Read the thesis statement Read the topic sentences Check the use of cohesive devices Check referencing Read the essay in detail This tells you a lot about what you should show in an essay to get a good score.

item.title: Are you hiding?
item.description: You don’t need talent to learn a language. Everyone is born with the capacity. There’s no secret to mastering one either.

item.title: Shadowing (speaking secret! ðŸ¤«)
item.description: I’m going to tell you one secret to native-like English speaking ability. Shh… don’t tell anyone. Just kidding. Everyone knows. The secret is “shadowing”: (1) find a speaker whose voice you like, (2) pick a video by that person, and (3) try to copy their speech perfectly (which takes a tremendous amount of time, but is totally doable)

item.title: Trust the process
item.description: My younger boy has been learning to walk for a couple months now. And today he suddenly started to walk unaided, 5-6 paces each time.

item.title: Listening first
item.description: Just like [[reading/easy-hard|reading]], getting 9 for listening isn’t hard. Well, I admit that it is a bit harder since you’ll have to give 100% focus.

item.title: One step at a time
item.description: In each of the post on this site, I’ll highlight a word or a phrase that might be interesting or helpful to you.

item.title: Reading 9
item.description: Getting a 9 for reading can be hard for many candidates, but to me (at least in the last exam) it’s not too big of a challenge.

item.title: Good writing is natural writing
item.description: A good piece of writing is one that sounds natural. Read this sentence: I do believe that spending a large part of leisure time on utilizing cellphones is a negative trend.

item.title: Simple but correct
item.description: [!success] Did you know… Simpler but correct language will earn you a better score for vocabulary than inaccurate usage of “advanced” words and phrases.
